p: Species richness and evenness provide intuitive, relevant measures that can be easily understood and communicated. Many studies have relied solely on species richness or evenness as a measure of diversity (e.g., [ 28, 29, 76, 77]), and they can be somewhat responsive to management (fire [ 17, 78]; deer control [ 55]; fire and thinning [ 79]), or relatively unaffected by them (deer control [ 80]).
